questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of right-sided painless scrotal swelling that he noticed yesterday while taking a shower. He is currently sexually active with two female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. He immigrated to the US from Argentina 2 years ago. His immunization records are unavailable. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 5 years. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. He appears healthy and well-nourished. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft with dull lower abdominal discomfort. Testicular examination shows a solid mass in the right testis that is firm and nontender. A light held behind the scrotum does not shine through. The mass is not reduced when the patient is in a supine position. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In patients with orchitis, testicular swelling is a common finding. Also, this patient's sexual behavior puts him at risk of contracting a sexually transmitted infection that may cause orchitis. In cases of orchitis, though, the scrotum usually appears inflamed (erythema over the overlying skin), the affected testicle is very tender, and patients often present with systemic symptoms such as fever and chills. This patient is afebrile and his scrotum is not inflamed, suggesting a different diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Varicocele may manifest as a painless, firm scrotal swelling that does not transilluminate. Patients typically present with visible or palpable strands (“bag of worms”) rather than a solitary nodule. Varicoceles are usually reduced when in the supine position because of decreased hydrostatic pressure within the venous plexus. The presence of a firm testicular mass that does not reduce in supine position makes another diagnosis more likely.

In contrast to most primary varicoceles, which reduce upon laying down, secondary varicoceles do not reduce in the supine position. Secondary varicoceles are due to compression of the venous drainage of the testicle, which can be caused by tumors of the retroperitoneum (e.g., renal cell carcinoma, lymphoma) or retroperitoneal fibrosis. Secondary varicoceles warrant further evaluation.

C) INCORRECT:

A hydrocele testis manifests as a nontender unilateral or bilateral scrotal swelling adjacent to the testis. However, a hydrocele is usually elastic rather than firm on palpation, and it does transilluminate.

D) INCORRECT:

A spermatocele testis may manifest as a nontender swelling within the scrotum. However, this condition usually involves swelling of the epididymis rather than the testis, and a spermatocele does transilluminate. Because this patient has a negative transillumination test and a firm testicular swelling, a different diagnosis is more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

A scrotal hernia may cause testicular swelling and dull abdominal discomfort. However, in a patient with a scrotal hernia, a visible or palpable groin protrusion would be expected, which may fluctuate in size and is usually more pronounced in the upright than in the supine position. Also, a hernia would be elastic rather than firm on palpation and may be felt as a swelling extending up the spermatic cord to the external inguinal ring. Since these features are not present in this patient, a different diagnosis is more likely.

F) INCORRECT:

Epididymitis typically manifests with scrotal swelling, and this patient's sexual behavior does put him at risk of developing bacterial epididymitis. But epididymitis is usually associated with severe testicular pain and manifests with dysuria, as well as both systemic (fever) and local signs of inflammation (induration, erythema, warmth). This patient has painless swelling, his scrotum does not appear inflamed, and he is afebrile, suggesting a different diagnosis.

G) CORRECT:

A testicular tumor is the most common solid malignancy in young men and should be suspected in a patient with a firm testicular swelling and a negative transillumination test. Given this patient's age and clinical presentation, suspicion of a testicular malignancy is high, and a scrotal ultrasound should be obtained. If malignancy is suspected on ultrasound, baseline tumor markers (AFP, hCG, LDH) should be measured. Patients with a suspicious testicular mass should undergo radical inguinal orchiectomy (RIO) after cryopreservation of sperm. Following RIO, staging diagnostics (e.g., postoperative tumor markers and imaging) are obtained to guide postsurgical management. The overall prognosis of testicular tumors is excellent, with a high cure rate and 5-year survival rates of > 95%.

See “Differential diagnosis of painless testicular swelling” table.
questions.hint: A scrotal ultrasound in this patient might reveal disseminated calcifications (starry sky appearance).

questions.text: A 33-year-old man comes to the physician because of right scrotal swelling for the past 2 weeks. He has had mild lower abdominal discomfort for the past 3 weeks. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows gynecomastia. There is no inguinal lymphadenopathy. There is a firm nontender nodule over the right testicle. When a light is held behind the scrotum, it does not shine through. When the patient is asked to cough, the nodule does not cause a bulge. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The liver is palpated 2 cm below the right costal margin. Digital rectal examination is unremarkable. Serum alpha-fetoprotein, LDH, and hCG levels are markedly elevated. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. Ultrasound of the testis shows a cystic 3-cm mass with variable echogenicity. A CT of the abdomen shows multiple hypoattenuating lesions on the liver and retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Radical inguinal orchiectomy with retroperitoneal lymph node dissection is performed. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

External beam radiation is used to clear the retroperitoneal lymph nodes off of micro-/macrometastases in early stage (I, IIA, IIB) seminomatous germ cell tumors, which are extremely radiosensitive. However, radiation therapy is generally not used in the treatment of NSGCTs because these tumors are comparatively radioresistant. The only indication for radiation therapy in patients with a NSGCT is brain metastases (e.g., whole brain irradiation).

B) CORRECT:

Adjuvant chemotherapy with cisplatin, etoposide, and bleomycin (BEP regimen) can be considered in stage I nonseminoma in select patients and is usually indicated in stages II and III. This patient has signs of advanced NSGCT with metastases to his liver and increased tumor markers (stage IIIC). In addition to the radical inguinal orchiectomy, he would likely require 4 cycles of this regimen due to the advanced nature of his cancer.

Patients with nonseminomas have a significantly poorer prognosis than patients with seminomas, but still an excellent overall survival rate.

C) INCORRECT:

The combination of leucovorin, 5-fluorouracil, and oxaliplatin (FOLFOX) is used for the treatment of colorectal cancer. It is not used for testicular cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

After an inguinal orchiectomy, active surveillance consisting of regular follow-up exams, serial monitoring of tumor markers, and imaging (abdominal and pelvic CT, chest x-ray) may be indicated in select patients with early-stage (IA, IB) nonseminomatous germ cell tumors (NSGCTs) without elevated tumor markers. However, any NSGCT of stage II and above or any NSGCT with elevated tumor markers requires a specific form of adjuvant therapy after orchiectomy.

E) INCORRECT:

A peripheral blood stem cell transplantation is indicated for patients who require high-dose chemotherapy, which has a myeloablative effect. However, high-dose chemotherapy is preferred in testicular cancer over conventional chemotherapy only in patients with an incomplete response or recurrent disease following the first-line of adjuvant therapy. Stem cell transplantation is not required following the conventional first-line adjuvant therapy.
questions.hint: A nonhomogenous, cystic testicular mass with a negative transillumination test and multiple hepatic and lymphatic lesions is highly suggestive of metastatic testicular carcinoma. Extranodal/distant metastases at the time of presentation and increased alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels make a nonseminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT) the most likely type of tumor in this patient.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of left testicular swelling. He has no pain. He underwent a left inguinal hernia repair as a child. He takes no medications. He appears healthy. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an enlarged, nontender left testicle. When the patient is asked to cough, there is no bulge present in the scrotum. When a light is held behind the scrotum, it does not shine through. There is no inguinal lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
14.5 g/dL


Leukocyte count
8800/mm3



Platelet count
345,000/mm3



Serum



 Glucose
88 mg/dL


 Creatinine
0.8 mg/dL


 Total bilirubin
0.7 mg/dL


 Alkaline phosphatase
35 U/L


 AST
15 U/L


 ALT
14 U/L


 Lactate dehydrogenase
60 U/L


 β-Human chorionic gonadotropin


80 mIU/mL (N < 5)


 α-Fetoprotein
6 ng/mL (N < 10)


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Varicoceles typically manifest as a left-sided, enlarged, nontender scrotal mass that does not transilluminate. These lesions are caused by dilation of the pampiniform plexus due to proximal obstruction of the spermatic vein and, as a result, typically manifest with soft, palpable strands that make the affected scrotum appear like a bag of worms. Varicoceles more commonly develop in the left hemiscrotum because the left spermatic vein, which drains into the left renal vein, often has higher intravascular pressure than the right due to compression of the left renal vein by the aorta and superior mesenteric artery. Unlike this patient's mass, varicoceles typically bulge with increased intraabdominal pressure (e.g., when coughing). Moreover, these lesions are not associated with an increased serum β-hCG concentration.

B) INCORRECT:

A testicular teratoma is a germ cell tumor that can manifest as an enlarged scrotal mass that does not transilluminate. Teratomas do not produce β-hCG, but the presence of an increased serum β-hCG concentration can indicate the presence of additional germ cell tumors (i.e., a mixed germ cell tumor). Compared to other testicular tumors of adulthood, teratomas are relatively rare and not the most likely diagnosis in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

A Leydig cell tumor can manifest as an enlarged scrotal mass that does not transilluminate. However, these rare tumors do not produce β-hCG. They can produce large amounts of sex hormones, which results in symptoms of androgen excess (e.g., growth of facial hair, deepening of the voice, male pattern baldness) and/or symptoms of estrogen excess (e.g., gynecomastia, erectile dysfunction, infertility), none of which are seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

A spermatocele can manifest as an enlarged, nontender scrotal mass that transilluminates, and does not bulge with increased intraabdominal pressure (e.g., when coughing). These lesions are caused by the accumulation of sperm, most commonly in the head of the epididymis. Thus, unlike this patient's mass, spermatoceles are usually distinct from the rest of the testicle.

E) INCORRECT:

Testicular choriocarcinoma can manifest with an enlarged, nontender scrotal mass. These tumors produce large amounts of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG). However, unlike this patient, who has a serum β-hCG concentration of 80 mIU/mL, patients with testicular choriocarcinoma typically have concentrations > 1,000 mIU/mL. Because the α-subunit of hCG is identical to LH, FSH, and TSH, patients with high levels of hCG can develop gynecomastia and/or symptoms of hyperthyroidism, which this patient does not have. Moreover, these tumors are rare and often metastasize early to the lungs and/or brain.

F) INCORRECT:

A yolk sac tumor can manifest with an enlarged, nontender scrotal mass. However, these tumors are rare among adults, not associated with an increased serum β-hCG concentration, and often produce large amounts of α-fetoprotein.

G) CORRECT:

Seminoma is the most common testicular germ cell tumor and almost exclusively occurs in adults (most commonly in the fourth decade of life). These tumors are typically slow-growing and manifest with a homogeneously enlarged, nontender scrotal mass that does not bulge with increased intraabdominal pressure (e.g., when coughing) or transilluminate. Seminomas that contain syncytiotrophoblasts can produce hCG, resulting in a mild increase in serum β-hCG (typically < 100 mIU/mL).

Radical inguinal orchiectomy is often curative for patients with seminoma. Depending on the extent of lymph node involvement, chemotherapy and radiotherapy can be used as adjunctive treatments.
questions.hint: Histopathologic examination of this patient's testicular lesion would show cells with clear cytoplasm and central nuclei (i.e., fried egg cell appearance).

questions.text: Ultrasonography of the scrotum shows a 2-cm hypoechoic, homogeneous testicular mass with sharp margins. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a single enlarged para-aortic lymph node. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Radiation therapy to the para-aortic and ipsilateral iliac LNs is indicated in the management of stage II seminoma, which manifests with an enlarged para-aortic LN on abdominal CT scan (chest imaging is required for complete staging). Seminomas are the most common type of testicular cancer and can cause increased serum β-hCG concentration. However, histopathologic evidence of seminoma is required before initiation of radiation therapy in a patient with a testicular mass.

B) INCORRECT:

Systemic polychemotherapy is indicated as an adjuvant treatment once primary treatment for testicular cancer has been completed and as a primary treatment in patients with symptomatic metastatic disease (e.g., dyspnea, back pain, weight loss) and rapidly rising tumor markers. However, this patient does not have symptoms that suggest metastatic disease and has not received primary treatment yet.

C) INCORRECT:

Scrotal orchiectomy is contraindicated when a testicular mass has features suggestive of an underlying malignancy. Removal of a testicular tumor through a scrotal incision risks seeding of tumor cells within the scrotum and, therefore, risks metastasis to a group of LNs that would normally not be involved in testicular cancer. The lymphatic drainage of the testes is into the retroperitoneal LNs, while that of the scrotum drains into the inguinal LNs.

D) INCORRECT:

A transscrotal needle biopsy of a testicular mass is contraindicated when there are features that suggest an underlying malignancy. A needle biopsy of a testicular tumor risks seeding of tumor cells within the scrotum and, therefore, risks metastasis to a group of LNs that would normally not be involved in testicular cancer. The lymphatic drainage of the testes is into the retroperitoneal LNs, while that of the scrotum drains into the inguinal LNs.

E) CORRECT:

Radical inguinal orchiectomy (RIO) is indicated for any testicular mass that has features that suggest an underlying malignancy. Regardless of the stage of the tumor, RIO is the first step in management, as it is necessary to confirm the diagnosis of testicular cancer and to classify it according to its histologic subtype (e.g., seminoma, nonseminomatous germ cell tumor). The inguinal approach is preferred, as it permits a high ligation of the spermatic cord that contains the testicular blood vessels and lymphatics. This technique helps minimize tumor dissemination. The testicular lymphatic channels travel in the spermatic cord and drain into the retroperitoneal LNs (e.g., the para-aortic LNs).

Because malignancy, orchiectomy, and adjuvant therapy compromise fertility, cryopreservation of sperm should be offered prior to initiating therapy.

F) INCORRECT:

An open testicular biopsy is contraindicated when a testicular mass has features that strongly suggest an underlying malignancy, due to the risk of dissemination of tumor cells. An open testicular biopsy can be performed when there is insufficient evidence of malignancy (e.g., undetectable serum tumor markers) or when a testicular mass is detected in individuals with a solitary testis.
questions.hint: This patient's intratesticular mass on sonography and mildly increased serum β-hCG concentration (a nonspecific testicular tumor marker) are strongly suggestive of testicular cancer. His CT scan findings, which indicate metastasis to the regional lymph nodes (LNs), do not affect the initial management in this patient.

questions.text: A previously healthy 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because he has increased facial and axillary hair. There is no family history of serious illness. He is at 95th percentile for height and weight. Examination shows coarse pubic and axillary hair. The penis and left testicle are enlarged. Serum concentrations of human chorionic gonadotropin and alpha-fetoprotein are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Leydig cell tumors are rare testicular tumors that usually develop after the age of 4. The tumors typically manifest as painless testicular masses and produce large amounts of testosterone as well as smaller amounts of estrogen, progesterone, and corticosteroids. The excess in androgens leads to precocious pseudopuberty in boys with prominent external genitalia, accelerated skeletomuscular development, mature masculine voice, and growth of facial, axillary, and pubic hair. GnRH, FSH, and LH levels are decreased in response to the elevated androgen levels in precocious pseudopuberty. The treatment of Leydig-cell tumors consists of surgical resection using radical inguinal orchiectomy.

See “Overview of testicular tumors” table.

B) INCORRECT:

Teratomas are more common in children and can manifest with a painless testicular mass and typically normal alpha-fetoprotein and human chorionic gonadotropin levels. However, they usually do not secrete hormones and thus do not cause precocious puberty.

C) INCORRECT:

Seminomas can manifest with a painless testicular mass and normal alpha-fetoprotein and human chorionic gonadotropin levels. However, these tumors have a peak incidence in the fourth decade of life and do not cause precocious puberty.

D) INCORRECT:

Sertoli cell tumors can manifest with a painless testicular mass and normal alpha-fetoprotein and human chorionic gonadotropin levels. However, these tumors are more common in older males (with a peak incidence of around 40 years). Furthermore, although Sertoli cell tumors can also produce hormones, they more commonly secrete estrogen so that gynecomastia, rather than virilization is seen.

E) INCORRECT:

Choriocarcinoma can also present as a painless testicular mass and cause precocious puberty if it occurs in young children such as in this patient. However, human chorionic gonadotropin levels are usually markedly increased (which causes precocious puberty secondary to increased production of testosterone).

F) INCORRECT:

Lymphomas can manifest with a painless testicular mass and normal alpha-fetoprotein and human chorionic gonadotropin levels. However, these tumors are more common in adults and do not cause precocious puberty. Additionally, other symptoms, such as weight loss, fever, or night sweats, are often present.
questions.hint: Laboratory studies in this patient would likely show elevated testosterone and estrogen levels.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a progressive development of tender breast tissue over the past 6 months. He used to ride his bicycle for exercise 4 times a week but stopped after he had an accident and injured his left testicle 3 months ago. He has gained 5 kg (11 lb) during this period. For the last 10 years, he has had one to two beers daily and sometimes more on weekends. He occasionally takes pantoprazole for heartburn. He is 171 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 87 kg (192 lb); BMI is 30 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows bilaterally symmetrical, mildly tender gynecomastia. A nontender 1.5-cm mass is palpated in the left testis; transillumination test is negative. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?

choices.text: Non-germ cell tumor of the testis

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A solid testicular mass should be considered testicular cancer until proven otherwise. The presence of features of estrogen excess (gynecomastia) in combination with a nontransilluminating testicular mass suggests a hormone-producing testicular tumor, most likely a non-germ cell tumor of the testis (e.g., Sertoli cell tumor or Leydig cell tumor). Endocrinological features of either masculinization (e.g., precocious puberty, temporal hair recession, increased musculature) or feminization (e.g., gynecomastia, erectile dysfunction, loss of libido) occur in only one-third of patients. Non-germ cell tumors of the testes arise from the supporting tissue of the testes and therefore do not result in elevated tumor markers (alpha fetoprotein, beta HCG, lactate dehydrogenase).

Scrotal ultrasound can help determine the origin of the mass, i.e., either the testes or adjacent structures (e.g., epididymis). Ipsilateral radical inguinal orchiectomy and histopathology are necessary for a definitive diagnosis. A transcrotal biopsy is not recommended because of the increased risk of tumor seeding into the scrotum and scrotal lymphatics.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased subcutaneous fat deposition can cause painless bilateral breast enlargement in obese males. This condition is known as pseudogynecomastia as there is no increase in mammary glandular tissue. Although this patient is obese (BMI of 30 kg/m2), the presence of tender gynecomastia and a testicular mass makes obesity a less likely cause of his gynecomastia.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism may cause pseudogynecomastia due to weight gain and deposition of subcutaneous fat in the mammary region. Although this patient has a recent increase in weight, he also has a recent decrease in physical activity (he stopped cycling), and he has no other clinical features of hypothyroidism (e.g., cold intolerance, constipation, dry skin). Moreover, the presence of a testicular mass in this patient makes another diagnosis more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Individuals with Klinefelter syndrome have hypergonadotropic hypogonadism that begins around puberty because of progressive damage to the testosterone-producing Leydig cells. Gynecomastia, developing around puberty, is a common feature of Klinefelter syndrome due to low testosterone production. However, this patient's age, the absence of other features of hypogonadism (e.g., decreased body hair, excessively long limbs, small testes), and the unilateral testicular mass rule out Klinefelter syndrome as the cause of his symptoms. Individuals with Klinefelter syndrome are at a higher risk of developing breast cancer (due to the excessive estrogen) and at a lower risk of developing prostate cancer (due to the lack of testosterone).

E) INCORRECT:

Liver cirrhosis can cause hyperestrogenism and subsequent gynecomastia as the cirrhotic liver is unable to metabolize estrogen. Although alcohol consumption is an important risk factor for the development of liver cirrhosis, this patient does not have other clinical features of either compensated liver cirrhosis (e.g., anorexia, weight loss, fatigue) or decompensated liver cirrhosis (e.g., jaundice, pruritus, ascites). In addition, the presence of a testicular mass in this patient makes another diagnosis more likely.

F) INCORRECT:

Testicular trauma can lead to a scrotal hematocele, which manifests with a unilateral nontransilluminating scrotal swelling. However, a scrotal hematocele would not cause a testicular mass and is unlikely to manifest as late as 3 months after the injury. Testicular atrophy (e.g., after significant trauma, or, if a large undrained hematoma has caused pressure atrophy of the testis) is a late complication of testicular trauma that could potentially manifest with gynecomastia. However, only bilateral testicular atrophy would cause gynecomastia due to decreased testosterone production. A unilateral palpable testicular mass is consistent with another diagnosis.

G) INCORRECT:

Drugs that inhibit testosterone receptors (e.g., cimetidine, spironolactone), testosterone synthesis (e.g., finasteride, ketoconazole), or which stimulate estrogen synthesis (e.g., digitalis) can cause gynecomastia. Proton pump inhibitors have also been associated with an increased risk of developing gynecomastia (mechanism unknown). However, the combination of gynecomastia and a testicular mass strongly suggests a different cause.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a solid testicular mass and gynecomastia, which is likely caused by an increased estrogen/testosterone ratio.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of lump on his right testicle that he noticed 2 weeks ago while bathing. He has a history of bilateral cryptorchidism treated with orchidopexy at 8 months of age. Physical examination shows a firm, nontender nodule on the right testis that does not transilluminate. His serum alpha-fetoprotein, placental alkaline phosphatase, and beta-human chorionic gonadotropin concentration are all within the reference range. This patient's testicular tumor is most likely of which of the following types?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Testicular germ cell tumors are divided into two groups: seminomas (most common) and nonseminoma tumors. Nonseminoma tumors include embryonal carcinomas, yolk sac tumors, testicular choriocarcinomas, teratomas, and tumors with mixed germ cell histology. Pure teratomas typically do not cause an elevation in testicular tumor markers (beta-hCG, AFP, PLAP), which is consistent with this patient's laboratory studies. Teratomas are more common in children but are usually benign in this patient group. In adult males, they are rare but more often malignant.

Unlike hydroceles, testicular tumors do not transilluminate on examination. Typically, testicular tumors should not be percutaneously biopsied because a biopsy can cause seeding of malignant cells in the scrotum.

B) INCORRECT:

Cryptorchidism is not a risk factor for non-germ cell tumors such as Sertoli cell tumors. Moreover, Sertoli cell tumors are very rare, accounting for < 1% of all testicular cancers in adults.

C) INCORRECT:

Cryptorchidism is not a risk factor for non-germ cell tumors such as Leydig cell tumors. Moreover, Leydig cell tumors are very rare, accounting for only approx. 2% of all testicular cancers in adults.

D) INCORRECT:

Yolk sac tumors are nonseminomatous germ cell tumors. While this patient's history of bilateral cryptorchidism puts him at increased risk of developing germ cell tumors, he is unlikely to develop a yolk sac tumor because it most commonly manifests before puberty. Moreover, yolk sac tumors are associated with an increased level of AFP, which is normal in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Testicular lymphoma is the most common testicular tumor in men > 60 years of age. It usually arises when non-Hodgkin lymphoma metastasizes to the testicles. This 30-year-old man is unlikely to have a testicular lymphoma, and cryptorchidism is not a risk factor for testicular lymphoma.
questions.hint: Men with a history of cryptorchidism are at increased risk for testicular germ cell tumors, even after cryptorchidism has been surgically repaired.

questions.text: A previously healthy 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of anxiety, diarrhea, and a 4.1-kg (9-lb) weight loss. On questioning, he also reports that he noticed a painless mass on his left testicle 2 weeks ago. His pulse is 110/min and irregular and blood pressure is 150/70 mm Hg. Examination shows diaphoresis and a fine tremor of the outstretched fingers. Testicular examination shows a 3-cm, firm, nontender mass on the left scrotum that does not transilluminate. This patient's underlying condition is most likely to be associated with which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Proptosis is associated with hyperthyroidism due to Graves disease. While this patient's symptoms are suggestive of hyperthyroidism, he has no evidence of Graves disease (e.g., diffuse goiter or pretibial myxedema). Furthermore, Graves disease would not account for his testicular mass.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum AFP levels are seen in men with certain nonseminomatous germ cell tumors, mainly yolk sac tumors and, less commonly, embryonal carcinoma. While this patient's testicular mass is highly suggestive of a testicular tumor, AFP-producing testicular tumors would not account for his symptoms of hyperthyroidism.

C) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum TSH is seen in primary hypothyroidism. This patient has symptoms of hyperthyroidism, which would be associated with low serum TSH. High circulating levels of thyroid hormones in patients with hyperthyroidism suppress secretion of TSH through feedback inhibition.

Central hyperthyroidism would cause elevated levels of serum TSH, but it would not account for this patient's testicular mass.

D) INCORRECT:

Positive urine metanephrines are seen in pheochromocytoma, which is associated with symptoms of adrenergic overactivity. The classic symptom triad of pheochromocytoma (episodic headache, sweating, and tachycardia) overlaps with the symptoms of hyperthyroidism present in this patient. However, this patient's testicular mass should raise suspicion for testicular cancer, which would not cause urine metanephrines to be elevated.

E) CORRECT:

Testicular tumors can produce elevated circulating levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG). Because the alpha subunits of hCG and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) are identical and the beta subunits of these hormones are structurally very similar, hCG is able to weakly stimulate TSH receptors, resulting in the release of thyroid hormones. In rare cases, conditions with extremely high levels of hCG (e.g., choriocarcinoma, as is the likely diagnosis in this man, or gestational trophoblastic disease in women) may be associated with paraneoplastic hyperthyroidism.

The alpha subunit of hCG is also identical to the alpha subunits of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).
questions.hint: The incidental finding of a testicular mass that does not transilluminate should raise suspicion for testicular cancer. Additionally, the patient's symptoms (anxiety, diarrhea, and weight loss) and other physical examination findings (tachyarrhythmia, hypertension with widened pulse pressure, diaphoresis, fine tremor) are classic features of hyperthyroidism. Paraneoplastic hyperthyroidism is a possible complication of testicular choriocarcinomas.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of a painless testicular mass that he first noticed while showering. He is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. He does not smoke cigarettes. Physical examination of the right testicle shows a firm, fixed, nontender 2-cm nodule. When a light is held to the scrotum, there is no transillumination. Ultrasound shows a well-defined, homogenous, hypoechoic 2.3 cm lesion in the right testicle. Laboratory studies show increased serum concentrations of β-hCG and placental alkaline phosphatase, and a serum alpha-fetoprotein concentration that is within the reference range. Right radical inguinal orchiectomy is performed. A photomicrograph of a section of the removed testicle is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Yolk sac tumors are testicular germ cell tumors that are more common in prepubertal individuals. These tumors are classically associated with an increased serum concentration of AFP, not β-hCG or PLAP. Moreover, biopsy results show characteristic Schiller-Duval bodies rather than the neoplastic germ cells with fried-egg appearance seen here.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a testicular tumor sample (H&E stain; very high magnification)

A central blood vessel (red overlay) is surrounded by tumor cells (blue overlay) with enlarged nuclei and coarse chromatin, resulting in a glomerulus-like appearance (Schiller-Duval body).

Schiller-Duval bodies are a classic finding in yolk sac tumors. The diagnosis was confirmed by immunohistochemical findings (positive for α-fetoprotein and glypican 3).

B) INCORRECT:

Testicular lymphomas are aggressive secondary testicular tumors (typically non-Hodgkin lymphomas) that most commonly present in men > 60 years and are unlikely in a 32-year-old patient. Tissue biopsy would show clonal lymphocytes rather than germ cells. In addition, this patient's elevated β-hCG and PLAP serum concentrations are inconsistent with testicular lymphoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Choriocarcinomas, the most aggressive testicular germ cell tumor, can cause increased serum concentrations of β-hCG, but would not explain this patient's elevated serum PLAP concentration. Patients with choriocarcinoma often present in advanced stages with signs of metastases (e.g., hemoptysis or gastrointestinal symptoms), which are absent in this man. In addition, histopathological evaluation shows disorganized cytotrophoblasts and syncytiotrophoblasts with vascular invasion rather than the neoplastic germ cells with fried-egg appearance seen here.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of testicular tumor specimen (H&E stain; very high magnification)

Cytotrophoblasts are visible throughout the tumor in the form of polygonal-shaped cells with pale cytoplasm, enlarged oval nuclei, and distinct cell borders (examples indicated by arrowheads). Syncytiotrophoblasts are visible as multinucleated cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm (examples indicated by green overlay) surrounding the mononuclear cytotrophoblasts.

These findings are suggestive of choriocarcinoma. The diagnosis was confirmed by immunohistochemical findings (positive for β-hCG).

D) INCORRECT:

Teratomas that manifest in childhood are typically benign germ cell tumors, whereas those present in adults have a higher potential for malignancy. Unlike this patient's lab results, serum levels of β-hCG and PLAP are usually normal in patients with a pure teratoma. Furthermore, ultrasound findings in patients with teratoma show cysts and calcifications, not homogenous hypoechogenicity; biopsy would show tissue from multiple germinal layers (e.g., bone, teeth, hair).

E) INCORRECT:

Embryonal carcinomas are relatively rare testicular germ cell tumors that can cause increased levels of β-hCG, and (if pure) normal levels of AFP, but would not explain this patient's elevated serum PLAP concentration. In addition, embryonal carcinoma typically shows glandular/papillary morphology with areas of necrosis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of tumor tissue biopsy specimen (H&E stain; medium power magnification)

This testicular tumor tissue has a sheet-like (blue outline) and papillary architecture (green outlines; prominent fibrovascular cores indicated by black dashed lines). The tumor cells are pale, large, and epitheloid with prominent nucleoli (indicated by black arrowheads) and nuclear atypia. Necrotic areas (green overlay) and apoptotic bodies (examples marked by green arrowheads) are commonly seen. Gland-like or tubule-forming patterns (not seen here) may also occur.

The diagnosis of embryonal carcinoma should be confirmed with immunohistochemical stains (positive: CD30 and cytokeratins; negative: CD117/c-kit). Further stains should be performed in case of diagnostic uncertainty to rule out presence of a mixed germ-cell tumor.

F) CORRECT:

Increased β-hCG and PLAP serum concentrations and neoplastic germ cells with fried egg cell appearance (due to intracytoplasmic accumulation of glycogen) on testicular microscopy indicate that this patient's testicular tumor is a seminoma. Testicular tumors are the most common solid tumors in young men. Seminomas are the most common pure germ cell tumors and their incidence peaks in the fourth decade of life. As in this patient, early-stage testicular tumors can be treated with radical orchiectomy.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of testicular tumor (H&E stain; high magnification)

There is a solid growing tumor (green overlay) that consists of spermatogonia-like cells with clear to slightly granulated cytoplasm and large nuclei (white arrowheads). A tumor-associated lymphocytic infiltrate is visible (white overlay). For comparison, a normal testicular tubule (black outline) with normal spermatogonia (black arrowheads) is shown.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.
questions.hint: The histologic specimen shows tumor cells with central nuclei and lymphocytic infiltrate. Germ cells that exhibit a fried-egg appearance (i.e., clear cytoplasm and round nuclei) are a characteristic histologic finding in this tumor type.

questions.text:
A young man, 20 years of age, returns for follow-up one week after presenting with a left testicular mass. Examination confirms the presence of a round, firm mass, 2 cm by 1.5 cm, on the lateral left testicle, with no palpable lymphadenopathy.
Laboratory values for alpha-fetoprotein, beta human chorionic gonadotropin, and lactate dehydrogenase are all within normal limits. An ultrasound of the testicle reveals a heterogeneous, hypoechoic mass with associated calcifications. A chest radiograph is normal.
What is the most appropriate management in this case?

choices.text: External-beam radiation to the affected testicle
Excision of the mass with preservation of the affected testicle

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although external-beam radiation is useful after surgery in some settings, it is not used for primary treatment of a suspicious testicular mass.

B) INCORRECT:

Chemotherapy is not used before surgery in asymptomatic men with presumably localized testicular cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Current technologies do not allow for reliable excision of a suspicious testicular mass with preservation of the affected testicle.

D) INCORRECT:

Transscrotal orchiectomy can seed cancer cells into the scrotum and should be avoided.

E) CORRECT:

Testicular tumors are the most common solid tumors in young men. Most palpable testicular tumors in adults and older adolescents are malignant.

The most important initial diagnostic study in a young man with a testicular mass is ultrasonography. Even if serum tumor markers are not elevated, a solid, suspicious mass on ultrasound warrants a radical inguinal orchiectomy, both to confirm the diagnosis and as definitive treatment of early-stage disease.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management for a young man with a heterogeneous, hypoechoic testicular mass on ultrasound is radical inguinal orchiectomy.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man presents with a right testicular mass that has been growing for the past several months. He denies pain, dysuria, sexual dysfunction, or a history of sex without condoms. He underwent orchiopexy in his late teens for congenital cryptorchidism on the right side.
On physical examination, palpation of the scrotum reveals a hard, 8-mm mass in the upper pole of the right testicle. There is no inguinal lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the physical examination is normal.
An ultrasound of the testicle confirms the presence of the suspicious mass.
Which one of the following tumor markers is most likely to be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carbohydrate antigen 19-9 (CA 19-9) is not considered to be useful in patients with testicular tumors. CA 19-9 is used primarily in pancreatic cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is not considered to be useful in patients with testicular tumors. CEA is elevated in certain gastrointestinal tumors, some lung and breast cancers, and some cases of medullary thyroid cancer.

C) CORRECT:

Testicular tumors are the most common malignant tumors in young men. Most palpable testicular tumors in adults are malignant. Men with a history of cryptorchidism have an increased risk for the development of cancer in either testicle. The majority of testicular cancers in cryptorchid testicles are pure seminomas.

Human chorionic gonadotropin is a tumor marker that is typically elevated in patients with seminoma. It is thought to correlate more to the presence of trophoblast cells within the tumor than to the stage of the tumor.

Serum alpha-fetoprotein is only rarely elevated in patients with pure seminomas and, when detectable, is present only at low levels.

Orchiopexy before puberty reduces the risk for testicular cancer to a greater extent than orchiopexy after puberty. Orchiopexy is not necessary immediately after birth, because about half of cryptorchid testicles will descend spontaneously within the first 6 months of life.

Key learning point: The tumor marker most likely to be elevated in a young man with corrected cryptorchidism who presents with a suspicious testicular mass is human chorionic gonadotropin.

D) INCORRECT:

Cancer antigen 125 (CA-125) is not considered to be useful in patients with testicular tumors. CA-125 can be used as a tumor marker in women with ovarian cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

The majority of testicular cancers in cryptorchid testicles are pure seminomas. Serum alpha-fetoprotein is only rarely elevated in patients with pure seminomas and, when detectable, is present only at low levels.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old young man presents with a right testicular mass that has been growing for the past several months. He denies pain, dysuria, sexual dysfunction, or a history of sex without condoms. He underwent orchiopexy 5 years ago for congenital cryptorchidism on the right side.
On physical examination, palpation of the scrotum reveals a hard, 8-mm mass in the upper pole of the right testicle. There is no inguinal lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the physical examination is normal.
An ultrasound of the testicle confirms the presence of the suspicious mass.
Which one of the following tumor markers is most likely to be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serum alpha-fetoprotein is only rarely elevated in patients with pure seminomas and, when detectable, is present only at low levels.

B) INCORRECT:

Vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) is a catecholamine metabolite that may be elevated in the presence of a catecholamine-secreting tumor; neuroblastoma is the most common of these tumors in the pediatric age group, but pheochromocytomas or other neural crest tumors may also be associated with elevated levels.

C) CORRECT:

Testicular tumors are the most common solid tumors in young men, accounting for over 20% of all malignancies in males aged 15 to 39 years compared with 1% of malignancies in boys aged 1 to 10 years. Most palpable testicular tumors in young adults are malignant. Older adolescents and young men with a history of cryptorchidism have a 2.5- to 11-fold increased risk for the development of cancer in either testicle. The majority of testicular cancers in cryptorchid testicles are pure seminomas.

Human chorionic gonadotropin is a tumor marker that is typically elevated in patients with seminoma. It is thought to correlate more with the presence of trophoblast cells within the tumor than to the stage of the tumor.

Orchiopexy before puberty reduces the risk for testicular cancer to a greater extent than orchiopexy after puberty, but it does not completely eliminate the risk. Orchiopexy is not necessary immediately after birth, because about half of cryptorchid testicles will descend spontaneously within the first 6 months of life.

Key learning point: The tumor marker most likely to be elevated in a young man with corrected cryptorchidism who presents with a suspicious testicular mass is human chorionic gonadotropin.

D) INCORRECT:

Cancer antigen 125 (CA-125) can be used as a tumor marker in women with ovarian cancer but is not considered to be useful in patients with testicular tumors.

E) INCORRECT:

Homovanillic acid (HVA) is a catecholamine metabolite that may be elevated in the presence of a catecholamine-secreting tumor; neuroblastoma is the most common of these tumors in the pediatric age group, but pheochromocytomas or other neural crest tumors may also be associated with elevated levels.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the office because of a progressive development of tender breast tissue over the past 6 months. He has gained 5 kg (11 lb) during this period. He has one to two beers daily. He is 171 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 87 kg (192 lb); BMI is 30 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows bilaterally symmetrical, mildly tender gynecomastia. A nontender 1.5-cm mass is palpated in the left testis; transillumination test is negative. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?

choices.text: Non-germ cell tumor of the testis

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A solid testicular mass should be considered testicular cancer until proven otherwise. The presence of features of estrogen excess (gynecomastia) in combination with a nontransilluminating testicular mass suggests a hormone-producing testicular tumor, most likely a non-germ cell tumor of the testis (e.g., Sertoli cell tumor or Leydig cell tumor). Endocrinological features of either masculinization (e.g., precocious puberty, temporal hair recession, increased musculature) or feminization (e.g., gynecomastia, erectile dysfunction, loss of libido) occur in only one-third of patients. Non-germ cell tumors of the testes arise from the supporting tissue of the testes and therefore do not result in elevated tumor markers (alpha fetoprotein, beta HCG, lactate dehydrogenase).

Scrotal ultrasound can help determine the origin of the mass, i.e., either the testes or adjacent structures (e.g., epididymis). Ipsilateral radical inguinal orchiectomy and histopathology are necessary for a definitive diagnosis. A transcrotal biopsy is not recommended because of the increased risk of tumor seeding into the scrotum and scrotal lymphatics.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased subcutaneous fat deposition can cause painless bilateral breast enlargement in obese males. This condition is known as pseudogynecomastia as there is no increase in mammary glandular tissue. Although this patient is obese (BMI of 30 kg/m2), the presence of tender gynecomastia and a testicular mass makes obesity a less likely cause of his gynecomastia.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism may cause pseudogynecomastia due to weight gain and deposition of subcutaneous fat in the mammary region. Although this patient has a recent increase in weight, and he has no other clinical features of hypothyroidism (e.g., cold intolerance, constipation, dry skin). Moreover, the presence of a testicular mass in this patient makes another diagnosis more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Individuals with Klinefelter syndrome have hypergonadotropic hypogonadism that begins around puberty because of progressive damage to the testosterone-producing Leydig cells. Gynecomastia, developing around puberty, is a common feature of Klinefelter syndrome due to low testosterone production. However, this patient's age, the absence of other features of hypogonadism (e.g., decreased body hair, excessively long limbs, small testes), and the unilateral testicular mass rule out Klinefelter syndrome as the cause of his symptoms. Individuals with Klinefelter syndrome are at a higher risk of developing breast cancer (due to the excessive estrogen) and at a lower risk of developing prostate cancer (due to the lack of testosterone).

E) INCORRECT:

Liver cirrhosis can cause hyperestrogenism and subsequent gynecomastia as the cirrhotic liver is unable to metabolize estrogen. Although alcohol consumption is an important risk factor for the development of liver cirrhosis, this patient does not have other clinical features of either compensated liver cirrhosis (e.g., anorexia, weight loss, fatigue) or decompensated liver cirrhosis (e.g., jaundice, pruritus, ascites). In addition, the presence of a testicular mass in this patient makes another diagnosis more likely.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a solid testicular mass and gynecomastia, which is likely caused by an increased estrogen/testosterone ratio.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the office because of right-sided painless scrotal swelling that he noticed yesterday while taking a shower. He is currently sexually active with two female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. The abdomen is soft with dull lower abdominal discomfort. Testicular examination shows a solid mass in the right testis that is firm and nontender. A light held behind the scrotum does not shine through. The mass is not reduced when the patient is in a supine position. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In patients with orchitis, testicular swelling is a common finding. Also, this patient's sexual behavior puts him at risk of contracting a sexually transmitted infection that may cause orchitis. In cases of orchitis, though, the scrotum usually appears inflamed (erythema over the overlying skin), the affected testicle is very tender, and patients often present with systemic symptoms such as fever and chills. This patient is afebrile and his scrotum is not inflamed, suggesting a different diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

A spermatocele testis may manifest as a nontender swelling within the scrotum. However, this condition usually involves swelling of the epididymis rather than the testis, and a spermatocele does transilluminate. Because this patient has a negative transillumination test and a firm testicular swelling, a different diagnosis is more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

A scrotal hernia may cause testicular swelling and dull abdominal discomfort. However, in a patient with a scrotal hernia, a visible or palpable groin protrusion would be expected, which may fluctuate in size and is usually more pronounced in the upright than in the supine position. Also, a hernia would be elastic rather than firm on palpation and may be felt as a swelling extending up the spermatic cord to the external inguinal ring. Since these features are not present in this patient, a different diagnosis is more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Epididymitis typically manifests with scrotal swelling, and this patient's sexual behavior does put him at risk of developing bacterial epididymitis. But epididymitis is usually associated with severe testicular pain and manifests with dysuria, as well as both systemic (fever) and local signs of inflammation (induration, erythema, warmth). This patient has painless swelling, his scrotum does not appear inflamed, and he is afebrile, suggesting a different diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

A testicular tumor should always be suspected in patients with a firm testicular swelling and a negative transillumination test. Testicular tumors are the most common solid malignancy in men between 20–35 years of age. Therefore, in this patient, the suspicion for a testicular malignancy is very high and further evaluation is warranted. For further evaluation, a scrotal ultrasound is needed. If suspicion of testicular cancer remains high, a CT scan of the abdominopelvic region and the chest should be obtained for initial staging workup. In addition, tumor markers (AFP, HCG, LDH) should be measured. Patients with a suspicious testicular mass should undergo ipsilateral inguinal orchiectomy after cryopreservation of sperm.

See “Differential diagnosis of painless testicular swelling” table.
questions.hint: A scrotal ultrasound in this patient might reveal disseminated calcifications (starry sky appearance).

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents with a right testicular mass that has been growing for the past several months. He underwent orchiopexy in his late teens for congenital cryptorchidism on the right side. On physical examination, palpation of the scrotum reveals a hard, 8-mm mass in the upper pole of the right testicle. The remainder of the physical examination is normal. An ultrasound of the testicle confirms the presence of the suspicious mass. Which one of the following tumor markers is most likely to be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carbohydrate antigen 19-9 (CA 19-9) is not considered to be useful in patients with testicular tumors. CA 19-9 is used primarily in pancreatic cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is not considered to be useful in patients with testicular tumors. CEA is elevated in certain gastrointestinal tumors, some lung and breast cancers, and some cases of medullary thyroid cancer.

C) CORRECT:

Testicular tumors are the most common malignant tumors in young men. Most palpable testicular tumors in adults are malignant. Men with a history of cryptorchidism have an increased risk for the development of cancer in either testicle. The majority of testicular cancers in cryptorchid testicles are pure seminomas. Human chorionic gonadotropin is a tumor marker that is typically elevated in patients with seminoma. Orchiopexy before puberty reduces the risk for testicular cancer to a greater extent than orchiopexy after puberty. Orchiopexy is not necessary immediately after birth, because about half of cryptorchid testicles will descend spontaneously within the first 6 months of life.

Key learning point: The tumor marker most likely to be elevated in a young man with corrected cryptorchidism who presents with a suspicious testicular mass is human chorionic gonadotropin.

D) INCORRECT:

Cancer antigen 125 (CA-125) is not considered to be useful in patients with testicular tumors. CA-125 can be used as a tumor marker in women with ovarian cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

The majority of testicular cancers in cryptorchid testicles are pure seminomas. Serum alpha-fetoprotein is only rarely elevated in patients with pure seminomas and, when detectable, is present only at low levels.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of a lump on his right testicle that he noticed 2 weeks ago while bathing. He has a history of bilateral cryptorchidism treated with orchidopexy at 8 months of age. Physical examination shows a firm, nontender nodule on the right testis that does not transilluminate. His serum alpha-fetoprotein, placental alkaline phosphatase, and beta-human chorionic gonadotropin concentration are all within the reference range. This patient's testicular tumor is most likely of which of the following types?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Testicular germ cell tumors are divided into two groups: seminomas (most common) and nonseminoma tumors. Nonseminoma tumors include embryonal carcinomas, yolk sac tumors, testicular choriocarcinomas, teratomas, and tumors with mixed germ cell histology. Pure teratomas typically do not cause an elevation in testicular tumor markers (beta-hCG, AFP, PLAP), which is consistent with this patient's laboratory studies. Teratomas are more common in children but are usually benign in this patient group. In adult males, they are rare but more often malignant.

Unlike hydroceles, testicular tumors do not transilluminate on examination. Typically, testicular tumors should not be percutaneously biopsied because a biopsy can cause seeding of malignant cells in the scrotum.

B) INCORRECT:

Cryptorchidism is not a risk factor for non-germ cell tumors such as Sertoli cell tumors. Moreover, Sertoli cell tumors are very rare, accounting for < 1% of all testicular cancers in adults.

C) INCORRECT:

Cryptorchidism is not a risk factor for non-germ cell tumors such as Leydig cell tumors. Moreover, Leydig cell tumors are very rare, accounting for only approx. 2% of all testicular cancers in adults.

D) INCORRECT:

Yolk sac tumors are nonseminomatous germ cell tumors. While this patient's history of bilateral cryptorchidism puts him at increased risk of developing germ cell tumors, he is unlikely to develop a yolk sac tumor because it most commonly manifests before puberty. Moreover, yolk sac tumors are associated with an increased level of AFP, which is normal in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Testicular lymphoma is the most common testicular tumor in men > 60 years of age. It usually arises when non-Hodgkin lymphoma metastasizes to the testicles. This 30-year-old man is unlikely to have a testicular lymphoma, and cryptorchidism is not a risk factor for testicular lymphoma.
questions.hint: Men with a history of cryptorchidism are at increased risk for testicular germ cell tumors, even after cryptorchidism has been surgically repaired.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy comes for a routine checkup. His mother is concerned about when puberty begins. Which physical change typically signals the onset of male puberty?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Testicular enlargement is the earliest physical sign of puberty in boys, indicating activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. This process begins with increased pulsatile secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) from the hypothalamus, stimulating the anterior pituitary to release luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH). FSH stimulates Sertoli cells, leading to testicular growth and spermatogenesis, while LH promotes testosterone production from Leydig cells. The increase in testicular volume, often measured with an orchidometer, precedes other secondary sexual characteristics such as pubic hair growth and voice deepening.

Key learning point: The first sign of puberty in boys is usually testicular enlargement, indicating the onset of increased testosterone production.

B) INCORRECT:

Axillary hair development results from adrenal androgen secretion during adrenarche and typically follows early pubertal changes. It is not directly tied to the activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis, making it an atypical marker for the onset of puberty.

C) INCORRECT:

Voice deepening occurs later in male puberty due to testosterone-mediated changes in the larynx and vocal cords. It follows initial gonadal changes, such as testicular enlargement, which is the earliest and most reliable marker of puberty onset in boys.

D) INCORRECT:

Pubic hair growth can be influenced by adrenal androgens during adrenarche, which may occur independently of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis activation. While pubic hair may appear early, it is not a specific marker for the onset of gonadal puberty, which is better indicated by testicular enlargement.

questions.text: A previously healthy 6-year-old boy is brought to your clinic because of increased facial and axillary hair. There is no family history of serious illness. His height and weight are at the 95th percentile. On examination, he has coarse pubic and axillary hair, and both the penis and left testicle are enlarged. Serum concentrations of human chorionic gonadotropin and alpha-fetoprotein are within the reference range. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Teratomas are more common in children and can manifest with a painless testicular mass and typically normal alpha-fetoprotein and human chorionic gonadotropin levels. However, they usually do not secrete hormones and thus do not cause precocious puberty.

B) INCORRECT:

Seminomas can manifest with a painless testicular mass and normal alpha-fetoprotein and human chorionic gonadotropin levels. However, these tumors have a peak incidence in the fourth decade of life and do not cause precocious puberty.

C) INCORRECT:

Sertoli cell tumors can manifest with a painless testicular mass and normal alpha-fetoprotein and human chorionic gonadotropin levels. However, these tumors are more common in older males (with a peak incidence of around 40 years). Furthermore, although Sertoli cell tumors can also produce hormones, they more commonly secrete estrogen so that gynecomastia, rather than virilization is seen.

D) CORRECT:

Leydig cell tumors are rare testicular tumors that usually develop after the age of 4. The tumors typically manifest as painless testicular masses and produce large amounts of testosterone as well as smaller amounts of estrogen, progesterone, and corticosteroids. The excess in androgens leads to precocious pseudopuberty in boys with prominent external genitalia, accelerated skeletomuscular development, mature masculine voice, and growth of facial, axillary, and pubic hair. GnRH, FSH, and LH levels are decreased in response to the elevated androgen levels in precocious pseudopuberty. The treatment of Leydig-cell tumors consists of surgical resection using radical inguinal orchiectomy.

See “Overview of testicular tumors” table.

Key learning point: Leydig cell tumors in children secrete excess androgens, leading to precocious pseudopuberty with virilization and a painless testicular mass.

E) INCORRECT:

Choriocarcinoma can also present as a painless testicular mass and cause precocious puberty if it occurs in young children such as in this patient. However, human chorionic gonadotropin levels are usually markedly increased (which causes precocious puberty secondary to increased production of testosterone).
questions.hint: Laboratory studies in this patient would likely show elevated testosterone and estrogen levels.

questions.hint: This patient presents with a solid testicular mass and gynecomastia, which is likely caused by an increased estrogen/testosterone ratio.

In addition, tumor markers (AFP, HCG, LDH) should be measured. Patients with a suspicious testicular mass should undergo ipsilateral inguinal orchiectomy after cryopreservation of sperm.

See “Differential diagnosis of painless testicular swelling” table.

Key learning point: A firm, painless testicular mass with negative transillumination in a young man is highly suggestive of a testicular tumor and warrants prompt evaluation.

E) INCORRECT:

A spermatocele testis may manifest as a nontender swelling within the scrotum. However, this condition usually involves swelling of the epididymis rather than the testis, and a spermatocele does transilluminate. Because this patient has a negative transillumination test and a firm testicular swelling, a different diagnosis is more likely.
questions.hint: A scrotal ultrasound in this patient might reveal disseminated calcifications (starry sky appearance).

questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to your clinic with a right testicular mass that has been increasing in size over the past several months. He had an orchiopexy in his late teens for congenital cryptorchidism on the right side. On examination, there is a hard, 8-mm mass in the upper pole of the right testicle. The remainder of the examination is normal. Testicular ultrasound confirms a suspicious mass. Which one of the following tumor markers is most likely to be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Testicular tumors are the most common malignant tumors in young men. Most palpable testicular tumors in adults are malignant. Men with a history of cryptorchidism have an increased risk for the development of cancer in either testicle. The majority of testicular cancers in cryptorchid testicles are pure seminomas. Human chorionic gonadotropin is a tumor marker that is typically elevated in patients with seminoma. Orchiopexy before puberty reduces the risk for testicular cancer to a greater extent than orchiopexy after puberty. Orchiopexy is not necessary immediately after birth, because about half of cryptorchid testicles will descend spontaneously within the first 6 months of life.

Key learning point: The tumor marker most likely to be elevated in a young man with corrected cryptorchidism who presents with a suspicious testicular mass is human chorionic gonadotropin.

B) INCORRECT:

Carbohydrate antigen 19-9 (CA 19-9) is not considered to be useful in patients with testicular tumors. CA 19-9 is used primarily in pancreatic cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

The majority of testicular cancers in cryptorchid testicles are pure seminomas. Serum alpha-fetoprotein is only rarely elevated in patients with pure seminomas and, when detectable, is present only at low levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is not considered to be useful in patients with testicular tumors. CEA is elevated in certain gastrointestinal tumors, some lung and breast cancers, and some cases of medullary thyroid cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Cancer antigen 125 (CA-125) is not considered to be useful in patients with testicular tumors. CA-125 can be used as a tumor marker in women with ovarian cancer.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents to the ED with a 4-week history of painless left scrotal swelling and a sensation of heaviness. He denies trauma, fever, dysuria, or urethral discharge. Examination reveals a firm, nontender left testicular mass that does not transilluminate. Vital signs are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct — A firm, painless, nontransilluminating intratesticular mass in a young man is characteristic of a testicular tumor, most commonly a germ cell tumor. Ultrasound typically reveals a solid hypoechoic lesion. Recognition in the ED prompts urgent urologic referral, as early orchiectomy improves cure rates.

B) INCORRECT:

Epididymitis typically presents with acute pain, tenderness, and swelling that begins posteriorly and may improve with scrotal elevation. The absence of fever, dysuria, or tenderness argues against infection or inflammation.

C) INCORRECT:

Testicular torsion causes sudden, severe unilateral scrotal pain and a high-riding testis with absent cremasteric reflex. The gradual, painless course in this patient makes torsion highly unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Hydroceles typically present as soft, fluctuant, and transilluminating swellings. This patient’s mass is firm and nontransilluminating, suggesting another type of lesion instead of fluid accumulation.

E) INCORRECT:

Varicoceles feel like a “bag of worms” on palpation and often enlarge with Valsalva. They are usually compressible and located superior to the testis, not within it. The fixed, solid mass here is inconsistent with varicocele.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with a 3-week history of a right scrotal mass that was initially painless but is now causing him discomfort. He reports mild scrotal heaviness but denies fever, dysuria, or trauma. Physical examination shows a firm, nontender, 2-cm mass within the right testicle that does not transilluminate. The contralateral testicle is normal. Vital signs are normal. What is the most appropriate initial diagnostic step?

choices.text: Fine needle aspiration of the mass
CT of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While urgent urology consult is essential for suspected testicular tumors, the initial diagnostic workup should be performed first.

B) INCORRECT:

Fine needle aspiration or any form of transscrotal biopsy should not be performed if testicular tumor is suspected due to the risk of tumor seeding.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- Scrotal ultrasound is the first-line imaging study for any palpable scrotal abnormality or suspected testicular tumor. This initial diagnostic step guides subsequent management decisions, including the need for serum tumor markers and urgent urology consult.

D) INCORRECT:

CT of the abdomen and pelvis is performed as part of the staging diagnostics, but is obtained after radical inguinal orchiectomy and histopathological confirmation of testicular cancer. This imaging is not the initial diagnostic step for a suspected testicular mass.

E) INCORRECT:

Serum tumor markers (e.g., alpha-fetoprotein, human chorionic gonadotropin, lactate dehydrogenase) are an important part of the workup for suspected testicular cancer. However, serum markers are obtained after the malignancy has been confirmed and are not typically ordered in the emergency department.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of a painless lump in his right testicle and recent breast enlargement. He denies trauma, fever, or weight loss. He has a normal libido. On physical examination, a firm, non-tender, 2-cm mass is palpated in the right testis. There is bilateral, tender gynecomastia. A scrotal ultrasound confirms a solid, hypoechoic, intratesticular mass. Laboratory studies are significant for normal serum levels of alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation of a painless testicular mass, gynecomastia, and normal tumor markers (AFP and β-hCG) is classic for a Leydig cell tumor. These are non-germ cell (sex cord-stromal) tumors arising from the testosterone-producing Leydig cells. The tumor can secrete excess androgens which are then peripherally converted to estrogens via aromatase, or it may secrete estrogens directly, leading to signs of feminization like gynecomastia. While most are benign, about 10% are malignant. Leydig cell tumors are the most common type of sex cord-stromal tumor in adults.

B) INCORRECT:

Seminoma is the most common germ cell tumor and typically presents as a painless testicular mass in this age group. It is plausible because AFP is always normal, and β-hCG is normal in about 85% of cases. However, seminomas are not hormonally active in a way that directly causes gynecomastia, which is a prominent feature in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Embryonal carcinoma is a type of nonseminomatous germ cell tumor that presents as a testicular mass. This diagnosis is unlikely because these tumors almost always secrete tumor markers. Approximately 90% of patients with nonseminomatous germ cell tumors have an elevated AFP or β-hCG, both of which are normal in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Testicular lymphoma can present as a painless testicular mass. However, it is the most common testicular cancer in men over 50, making it less likely in a 35-year-old. Furthermore, lymphoma does not typically cause hormonal effects like gynecomastia and is often associated with systemic B symptoms, which this patient lacks.
questions.hint: This type of testicular tumor is typically benign, with malignant transformation occurring very rarely.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents with a three-week history of a dull ache and a sensation of heaviness in his right scrotum. He denies any recent trauma, fever, or dysuria. He recently started experiencing a persistent, mild lower backache. On physical examination, the right testis is diffusely enlarged and firm compared to the left. A 2-cm, hard, non-tender nodule is palpated within the testicular parenchyma. The epididymis and spermatic cord are unremarkable. The scrotum does not transilluminate. Vital signs are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for a testicular tumor, the most common solid malignancy in men aged 15-35. Key features include the insidious onset of a dull ache or heaviness and a painless, firm, non-tender, intratesticular mass on examination. The lack of transillumination confirms it is a solid mass. The new onset of lower back pain is a significant red flag for retroperitoneal lymph node metastasis, a common site of spread. The initial diagnostic workup includes a scrotal ultrasound to confirm an intratesticular mass and serum tumor markers (AFP, β-hCG, LDH). Radical inguinal orchiectomy is both diagnostic and therapeutic.

B) INCORRECT:

A hydrocele is a collection of peritoneal fluid within the tunica vaginalis, causing diffuse scrotal swelling. While it can cause a sensation of heaviness, it is typically a soft, cystic, non-tender mass that will transilluminate on examination. This patient has a hard, focal nodule that does not transilluminate, which is inconsistent with a hydrocele.

C) INCORRECT:

A varicocele is a dilation of the pampiniform plexus within the spermatic cord, often described as a 'bag of worms.' While it can cause a dull ache, it is a soft, compressible mass located superior to the testis, not an intratesticular nodule. The patient's examination revealed an unremarkable spermatic cord.

D) INCORRECT:

A spermatocele, or epididymal cyst, is a benign, cystic mass arising from the head of the epididymis, located superior and posterior to the testis. It is typically soft, painless, and transilluminates. The finding of a hard, solid mass located within the testicular parenchyma itself rules out a spermatocele.
questions.hint: New-onset back pain alongside a solid scrotal mass in a young adult male are important clinical considerations for this condition.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of testicular swelling and dull lower abdominal discomfort. Physical examination shows a firm, nontender left testicular nodule. Ultrasonography of the scrotum shows a well-defined hypoechoic lesion of the left testicle. Serum studies show an elevated β-hCG concentration and a normal α-fetoprotein concentration. The patient undergoes a radical inguinal orchiectomy. Histopathologic examination of the surgical specimen shows a mixed germ cell tumor with invasion of adjacent lymphatic vessels. Further evaluation is most likely to show malignant cells in which of the following lymph node regions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The external iliac lymph nodes are the primary sites of lymphatic drainage for the superior part of the bladder. They are not common sites of metastasis for testicular cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

The inferior mesenteric lymph nodes are the primary sites of lymphatic drainage for most of the large intestine (from the splenic flexure through the upper rectum, including the superior and sigmoid rectum). They are not common sites of metastasis for testicular cancer.
Image Description:

Lymph is ultimately drained into the systemic circulation via the subclavian veins. The right lymphatic duct only drains roughly the upper right area of the body (green), whereas the thoracic duct is responsible for the rest of the body. The deep lymph nodes are not palpable.

C) INCORRECT:

The internal iliac lymph nodes are the primary sites of lymphatic drainage for the prostate, corpus cavernosum, bladder, and the lower rectum (to the anal canal above the dentate line). They are not common sites of metastasis for testicular cancer.
Image Description:

Lymph is ultimately drained into the systemic circulation via the subclavian veins. The right lymphatic duct only drains roughly the upper right area of the body (green), whereas the thoracic duct is responsible for the rest of the body. The deep lymph nodes are not palpable.

D) INCORRECT:

The mediastinal lymph nodes are the primary sites of lymphatic drainage for the trachea and esophagus. Although malignant cells can appear in these nodes (as well as the hilar lymph nodes, which drain the lungs) if testicular cancers metastasize to the pulmonary system, this is not the primary region of lymphatic drainage for the testes. It is therefore less likely to have malignant cells than other lymph node clusters.
Image Description:

Lymph is ultimately drained into the systemic circulation via the subclavian veins. The right lymphatic duct only drains roughly the upper right area of the body (green), whereas the thoracic duct is responsible for the rest of the body. The deep lymph nodes are not palpable.

E) CORRECT:

The para-aortic lymph nodes are the most common site of metastasis for testicular cancer. Lymphatic fluid travels up the path of testicular descent through the inguinal canal, following the testicular arteries back to the abdominal aorta, where they originate, near the site of early gonadal development and differentiation of the mesonephros. The kidneys also drain to these lymph nodes.

Until proven otherwise, a firm nodule on the testis should be considered cancer.
Image Description:

Lymph is ultimately drained into the systemic circulation via the subclavian veins. The right lymphatic duct only drains roughly the upper right area of the body (green), whereas the thoracic duct is responsible for the rest of the body. The deep lymph nodes are not palpable.

F) INCORRECT:

The superficial inguinal lymph nodes are the primary sites of lymphatic drainage from the scrotum and distal anus up to the dentate line. They are not common sites of metastasis for testicular cancer.

G) INCORRECT:

The deep inguinal lymph nodes are the primary sites of lymphatic drainage for the glans penis and anterior urethra. They are not common sites of metastasis for testicular cancer.
questions.hint: This patient has a primary testicular cancer, which typically spreads through the lymphatic system. To remember which lymph nodes drain the testes, it is helpful to recall their location in early embryological development.
